results.headline: Apocalypse Now, but in the Wasteland a Child Is Given

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Children of Men

results.summary_short: “Children of Men,” the superbly directed political thriller by Alfonso Cuarón, may be something of a bummer, but it’s the kind of glorious bummer that lifts you to the rafters.

results.headline: Company Man: Hush, Hush, Sweet Operative

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Good Shepherd

results.summary_short: Directed by Robert De Niro, “The Good Shepherd” is an original story about the C.I.A., and for the filmmakers that story boils down to fathers who fail their sons.

results.headline: The Night of the Living Dioramas

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Night at the Museum

results.summary_short: “Night at the Museum" adheres to the current Hollywood philosophy that coherence doesn’t matter if enough stuff is thrown onto the screen.

results.headline: Stumbling for Gridiron Glory After a Crash

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of We Are Marshall

results.summary_short: “We Are Marshall” is the kind of crassly formulaic movie in which everything hinges on a single play in the final seconds of a big football game.

results.headline: Higgins, Meet Eliza, but It May Be Too Late

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Venus

results.summary_short: A modest, diverting, touching tale of a young woman who attracts the interest of an aging actor, played with effortless aplomb by the great Peter O’Toole.

results.headline: Dynastic Dysfunction and Loathing

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Curse of the Golden Flower

results.summary_short: The Chinese director Zhang Yimou achieves a kind of operatic delirium, opening the floodgates of image and melodrama until the line between tragedy and black comedy is all but erased.

results.headline: Blurring the Line in the Bleak Sands of Iwo Jima

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Letters From Iwo Jima

results.summary_short: Another masterwork from Clint Eastwood’s astonishing late period, and one of the best war movies ever.

results.headline: A Plague Infects the Land, as Passion Vexes Hearts

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Painted Veil

results.summary_short: The third film iteration of “The Painted Veil” turns W. Somerset Maugham’s distaff bildungsroman into a fine romance.

results.headline: Return of That Fighter With a Soft Heart Inside a Hard Body

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rocky Balboa

results.summary_short: Surprisingly, “Rocky Balboa” is no embarrassment. Like its forerunners it goes the distance almost in spite of itself.

results.headline: Leftist Politics Scampers Through Paris on Playful Paws
results.display_title: The Case of the Grinning Cat

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Case of the Grinning Cat

results.summary_short: In “The Case of the Grinning Cat,” the filmmaker Chris Marker fluidly moves over and under Paris, capturing images of fugitive beauty and pathos.

results.headline: An Artist Shows His Process by Way of a Film Within a Film

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Matthew Barney: No Restraint

results.summary_short: Alison Chernick’s aptly-named documentary takes us aboard a Japanese whaling vessel to witness the filming of the artist Matthew Barney’s film “Drawing Restraint 9.”

results.headline: White’s Country Critters, Still Humble

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Charlotte's Web

results.summary_short: Gary Winick’s film may not be perfect, but it honors its source and captures the key elements that have made E. B. White’s book a classic.

results.headline: She Will Not Speak. Words Fail Her.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Secret Life of Words

results.summary_short: As its title suggests, this eccentric film written and directed by Isabel Coixet contemplates the insufficiency of language to encapsulate traumatic experience.

results.headline: A Journey Through the Years With Duke Ellington

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Reminiscing in Tempo

results.summary_short: This documentary about Duke Ellington is too meandering to be of much use to the uninitiated, but Ellington fans will be grateful for the vintage film clips.

results.headline: Lives of Deception, Revealed in Extreme Close-Up

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Resilience

results.summary_short: Paul Bojack’s dour examination of unexamined lives is a slow-burning morality tale simmering with self-interest.

results.headline: A Life of Torment, Delusion and Decline

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Memoirs of My Nervous Illness

results.summary_short: The American actor Jefferson Mays is back in rouge and petticoats for “Memoirs of My Nervous Illness,” a punctilious account of madness and womb envy.

results.headline: Climbing Out of the Gutter With a 5-Year-Old in Tow

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Pursuit of Happyness

results.summary_short: A fairy tale in realist drag, “The Pursuit of Happyness” is the kind of entertainment that goes down smoothly until it gets stuck in your craw.

results.headline: Spies, Lies and Noir in Berlin

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Good German

results.summary_short: Steven Soderbergh attempts to resurrect the magic of classical Hollywood, principally by sucking out all the air, energy and pleasure from his own filmmaking.

results.headline: A Boy and His Dragon

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Eragon

results.summary_short: “Eragon” is what happens when misguided studio executives option a novel written by a teenager (Christopher Paolini) with a head full of Anne McCaffrey and Ursula K. Le Guin.

results.headline: Three-Part Heartbreak in Motown

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dreamgirls

results.summary_short: Audiences who go to “Dreamgirls” will have a good time, but they’ll be going for old time’s sake rather than to encounter anything vital or new.
